oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Papa's First Boat -- Steamer 'Alpha,'" by Leslie Ryman Barton
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A three-page narrative describing how Thomas Green Ryman bought his first boat with $3,000 sewn into the lining of his coat. The story describes the number of times the steamer "Alpha" ran aground or sank, claiming the boat sank 13 times, always on the 13th of the month. Also described is the first boat Ryman had built, the "Eddyville", in 1872. The narrative tells the fate of the "Alpha," including its decommissioning, and the sale prices of the vessel's parts.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daisy Ryman Coggins
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.
